sections.heading: Abstract:
sections.text:
In this research work we report synthesis of g-C3N4/FeVO4 (CI) and g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2Biochar (CIB) nano-hetero assemblies for removal of methyl paraben (MeP) and 2- cholrophenol (2-CP) via adsorption, photocatalysis and photo-ozonation. CI and CIB have been characterized by FT-IR, X-ray diffraction (XRD) , X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy(TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), UV-Vis spectroscopy, photoluminescence (PL), vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM), BraunerEmmet Teller surface area analyzer (BET). CIB shows good photocatalytic activity owing to higher specific area, nanosheet porous structure, stability, broader solar spectrum response and reduced charge carriers recombination. Fe@NH2-biochar facilitates the degradation via high adsorption capability due to reduced recombination, better charge separation, adsorption and acting of biochar as sink of electrons. The CIB photocatalytic system was tested under three experimental conditions for photodegradation of MeP and 2-CP; adsorption followed by photodegradation (AP); simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis (SAP); SAP+O3. An apparent
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
2
synergism between adsorption, photocatalysis and photo-ozonation brings out excellent and promising results. 98.4% of MeP and 90.7% of CP degradation was achieved under simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis in presence of CIB. The results were analyzed in terms of reaction kinetics, adsorption isotherms, scavenger effect, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS), Total Organic Carbon (TOC) analysis and cytotoxicity analysis of treated water. An efficient TOC removal 74.2 & 73.9 % for MeP and 2-CP were respectively achieved under SAP+O3+CIB photocatalysis system. Degradation pathways have been proposed for degradation of MeP and CP thorough photo-degradation and photo-ozonation. The cyto-toxicity studies on Human peripheral blood lymphocytes provide a reference for removal of noxious pollutants in real systems. This experimental work paves a way to design tuneable simple junctions for photocatalytic applications by utilizing various experimental protocols. Keywords: Nano-hybrid; Biochar; Photocatalysis; Adsorption; Pollutants

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rapid industrialization has led to increased discharge of noxious pollutants into water bodies. Among them phenolic compounds as nitrophenols, chlorophenols, bisphenol etc. are a huge threats (Sherly et al., 2015; Kumar et al., 2016. Chlorophenols (CPs) are one of the major pollutants as per U.S. EPA as they have mutagenic and carcinogenic activities and are a major component of dyes, herbicides etc. (Van Aken et al., 2017; (Yagmur et al., 2017). They are frequently discharged into industrial wastewater, and accumulated in ground and water bodies. Parabens are the alkyl and aryl esters of p-hydroxybenzoic acid, with bactericide and antimicrobial properties and found in the cosmetic and food products over a 13,200 formulations (Soni et al., 2001). Parabens cause breast cancer, endocrine disruption, skin aging and nucleic acid damage (Harvey et al., 2004; Benijts et al., 2003. Therefore, a growing concern has arisen in relation to their potential long-term effects on wildlife and human beings. In vivo studies have proven that long dermal exposure to parabens show a certain estrogenic and carcinogenic activity. Up to now, numerous methods have been reported in literatures for the treatment of waste water containing parabens and phenols, including physical adsorption, (Kant et al., 2014) biodegradation (Sharma et al., 2016), photodegradation (Hojaghan et al., 2017), photolysis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2/UV) (Nawrocki et al., 2010), fenton-like reactions (Wang et al.,2009)
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
or ozone oxidation (Zhao et al., 2015). Heterogeneous photocatalysis and ozonation have proved to be efficient tools for eliminating organic contaminants in wastewater (Nawrocki et al., 2010). Heterogeneous photocatalytic process seems to be an effective treatment technique due to its high degradation and mineralization efficiency, low toxicity, low cost, and ability to perform under ambient conditions The coupling of two different semiconductors does not only improve quantum yield, but also changes photo-absorption range of semiconductors. Very recently, graphitic carbon nitride (gC3N4), a metal-free, stable and inexpensive polymeric, has received increasing attention (Wang et L., 2009; Zhao et al., 2015). As a “sustainable” photocatalyst, g-C3N4 has many advantages, such as good thermal and chemical stability, metal-free and tunable electronic structure. Further, larger surface area and two-dimensional planar conjugation structure of g-C3N4 can provide a large platform for anchoring various substrates. However, the efficiency of g-C3N4 is reduced due to the low quantum efficiency and the high recombination rate of photo-generated electron– hole pairs. Coupling g-C3N4 with other semiconductors to form hetero-junction is an effective strategy to solve this problem (Ge et al., 2012; Hou et al., 2013. Up to now, several kinds of C3N4 based hetero-junctions have been successfully developed, C3N4/Bi2WO6 (Tian et al., 2013), C3N4/BiOBr (Fu et al., 2012). FeVO4 has been investigated for many years for its wide range potential applications. The FeVO4 has a triclinic structure with a band gap of 2.05eV band gap, and its absorption band edge extends up to 605nm (Wang et al., 2011). However, the activity of pure FeVO4 is low due to its poor adsorptive performance. Biochar is produced by combusting biomass under low oxygen conditions is attracting interest as a promising environmental remediation material (Xu et al., 2011). Biochar has porous structure, and possesses large surface area, it is not light-active and has a saturated adsorption capacity when it is used as pollutants adsorbents and can be used to remove both organic and inorganic contaminants from the environment. To enhance their capacity and selectivity for pollutant removal or stability for carbon-supported metallic catalysts, modification of carbon materials has been done. Nanocomposite sorbents with nano-sized metal oxyhydroxides attached onto carbonaceous surfaces within the biochar matrix have been successfully synthesized and demonstrated to have excellent abilities to remove a range of contaminants from aqueous solutions (Yao et al., 2011). Previous studies showed that the carbon materials in C3N4/carbon composites may act as cocatalysts to provide sufficient catalytic sites for photocatalytic degradation (Shi et al., 2014) and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
the conductive carbon materials can serve as efficient electron transfer channels and acceptors to improve the separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs. Because biochar can be easily obtained from waste biomass and produced at relatively low-cost, using biochar to support gC3N4/FeVO4 junction on magnetic NH2-modified biochar for environmental application is a potentially, environmentally and economically beneficial remediation strategy. In this research work we aim at designing of a sustainable nano-hybrid for environmental detoxification with synergism of adsorption, photocatalysis and photo-ozonation. 2. Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All chemicals used in present research were of AR grade. Ferric nitrate, ferric chloride, ammonium metavanadate, acetone, 2-chlorophenol and methylparaben were acquired from Sigma Aldrich and used without any extra purification. 2.2 Preparation of Fe0 loaded biochar Waste pinus needles (Pinus roxburrghii) were collected from pine forests of Himalayan region. Samples were chopped and then milled to uniform size of 0.5 –1 mm. These samples were washed several times with deionized water to remove dirt and dried at 80 °C for 24 h. The dried biomass about 500 g were fed into a stainless cylinder reactor (50 cm diameter) and purged with nitrogen gas. The samples were then placed in programmed muffle furnace with a heating rate of 10 °C /min at 600 °C. The sample was held at the peak temperature for 2 h. The biochar was then dipped in FeCl3 solution for 2 hours and then NaBH4 was added with stirring for 2h.The sample was then washed with ethanol and vacuum dried at 60 °C for 6h. 2.3 Preparation of Fe0@NH2-biochar Amino modified biochar was prepared as according to reported method (Yantasee et al., 2004). Typically, a mixture of 50 mL of conc. HNO3 and H2SO4 were added to R.B.D. flask bedecked with a mechanical stirring and cooled in an ice bath. Then Fe0 loaded biochar (5.0 g) was added to flask under continuous stirring for 2 h. The solid material was separated by vacuum filtration, washed with distilled water and isopropanol. The resulting contents were dried at 110 °C for the removal of the residual isopropanol for about 10 h. A suspension containing 5.0 g of obtained biomass, 50 mL of double distilled water, 20 mL of 15 M ammonium hydroxide, Na2S2O4 and 120 mL of 2.9 M CH3COOH was refluxed for 5h. The suspension was cooled, separated by
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
vacuum filtration & washed with double distilled water and isopropanol. The resulting product was dried overnight at 110 °C, and thus the Fe0@NH2-biochar was derived. 2.4 Preparation of Urea derived graphitic Carbon nitride. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) was prepared by the thermal treatment of urea. Typically, 10 g of urea was first heated at a rate of 2 °C min-1 to 550 °C for and then maintained at that temperature for 4h in a muffle furnace. A yellow fluffy product was collected and ground into powder. It was washed with distilled water and ethanol to remove any residual impurities adsorbed on the surface. The obtained g-C3N4 was vacuum dried at 60 °C.

sections.heading: 2.5 Preparation of g-C3N4/FeVO4 (CI)
sections.text: 0.250 g of g-C3N4 was firstly suspended in 250 mL of a 0.0042 M solution of ammonium metavanadate solution. The contents were stirred for 1h, then 30 ml of 0.26 M solution of iron nitrate was poured drop wise to this mixture and stirred for another 2h at 75 °C. The composite formed was precipitated which was separated from the liquid phase by centrifugation. Then the solid was washed with water and acetone several times, and finally dried at 50 °C for 15 h. The final product was labeled as CI. 2.6 Preparation of g-C3N4/FeVO4/ Fe@NH2-biochar (CIB) CI was synthesized as described above and then 0.5g of Fe@NH2-biochar was added. The same process was then repeated. The composite is then labeled as CIB.

sections.heading: 2.7 Characterization
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of as synthesized samples were recorded in the transmission mode between 4000 and 400 cm-1. Total surface area was measured using N2 sorption on a NOVA 1200 analyzer and calculated using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD, analysis was carried out with a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation over a 2θ collection range of 10–80o to examine possible sample crystallinity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Kratos Axis Ultra DLD instrument using a monochromated Al Kα irradiation. Elemental analysis was done by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy instrument equipped with SEM. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) was measured on a PHI5300 with a monochromatic Mg Kα source to explore the elements on the surface. The ultraviolet–visible spectra (UV–vis) were recorded using a Shimadzu 2202 double beam spectrophotometer; Magnetic studies were made using vibrating sample magnetometer (Microsense EV7, USA) up to field of 10,000 Oe. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was

used to document surface morphologies with H-7500 (JEM-1230 HC, JPN). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging was obtained from a JEOL-2011 TEM instrument. 2.8 Optical studies For optical studies, 0.005 g FeVO4 and g-C3N4 suspension in ethanol was prepared. The suspension was then ultrasonicated for 2 h. The UV–VIS spectrum was then recorded using a double -beam spectrophotometer. The direct band gaps were then calculated using the Tauc relation. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained at room temperature with a PerkinElmer LS 55 spectrometer with excitation wavelength of 320 nm.

sections.heading: 2.9 Adsorptional and photocatalytic removal of methyl paraben and 2-chlorophenol
2.9.1 Adsorptional removal (A)
sections.text:
For adsorptional removal, 50 mg of CIB or CI were added to 100 mL of 20mgL-1 solution of MeP/2-CP in distilled water. The solution was kept in dark for adsorption. After regular intervals absorbance at 255 nm was recorded using spectrophotometer for MeP. Similarly removal of 2- CP was studied by recording absorbance at 275nm. 2.9.2 Equilibrium adsorption followed by photodegrataion (AP)
In a typical experimental procedure 50 mg of photocatalyst (CIB or CI) were dispersed into 100
mL of solution containing 20mgL-1 of MeP or 2-CP. The suspension was stirred for 1 h in the dark to warrant the adsorption–desorption equilibrium between photocatalysts and MeP. Then the contents were kept in sunlight for degradation. 2.9.3 Simultaneous adsorption and Photocatalysis (SAP) In this system the suspension containing photocatalyst and target pollutant was immediately exposed to sunlight without keeping in dark. After defined intervals of time absorbance was recorded. The total organic carbon was analyzed using TOC 5000 analyzer, Shimadzu). After 30 min of photodegradation LC–MS analysis was carried out with a Thermo Scientific TSQ 8000 gas chromatograph–mass spectrometer.
2.10 Removal of MeP and 2-CP by photo-ozonation coupled with photocatalysis (SAP + O3) In this system ozonation was coupled with photocatalysis for degradation of MeP and 2-CP. Firstly ozone required for the process was produced from dry oxygen in a laboratory ozone generator. The aqueous ozone concentration was measured by the indigo method which is based on the decolorization of indigo trisulfonate by O3 (Bader et al., 1981). The solution containing dissolved ozone, photocatalyst and pollutant was exposed to sunlight without keeping in dark.

The hydrogen peroxide generated during photo-decomposition of ozone was analyzed following the cobalt colorimetric method (Masschelein et al., 1997). 2.11 Reusability To check the efficacy and reusability of photocatalyst for the photocatalytic experiments for photo-degradation of MeP and 2-CP were performed for 6 continuous cycles. 2.12 In vitro cytotoxicity evaluation:
The effect of the photocatalyst treated water on cell viability was assessed by MTT assay.
Human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) were purchased from Himedia and cultured in 10% RPMI-1640 medium in a 96-well plate. After 24 h of incubation, the medium was replaced with fresh 10% RPMI-1640 medium (treated water sample after mineralization of pollutant) and incubated overnight in 37 °C, 5% CO2. For MTT assay, 10 µl MTT (5 mg/ml) was added into each well to generate formazan, and then cells were incubated in humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 at 37 °C for 4 hrs. After removing the supernatant, 100 µl DMSO was added to dissolve the purple crystal with 10 min. The optical density of each well was measured at 595 nm by a microplate reader. Each sample was assayed in triplicate. The percentage viability was calculated by the following formula (equation 1)

3. Results and Discussion
3.1 Characterization

sections.heading: 3.1.1 FTIR analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 1 represents FTIR spectra of g-C3N4, g-C3N4/FeVO4 (CI), g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2-biochar (CIB) and Fe loaded biochar. For g- C3N4 the peak at 809 cm -1 corresponds to the s-triazine ring vibration (Yan et al., 2009). The peaks around 1236, 1570 and 1631 cm-1 corresponds to the typical stretching modes of C-N heterocycles, (Liao et al., 2012) a broad band around 3149 cm-1 is assigned to the N-H stretching vibration. In the FTIR spectrum of CI the absorption peaks for mixed bridging V-OˑˑˑFe stretching and Fe-O stretching (Vuk et al., 2012). V-O-V deformation appeared at 518 cm-1 (Vuk et al., 2001) and peak at 862 cm-1 refers to the terminal V-O stretching. Fe loaded biochar shows peaks at 1603 cm-1 , 1705 cm-1 and 3454 cm-1 which correspond to C=C , C=O and O-H stretching. In the FTIR spectrum of CIB we obtain broad

The peaks for g-C3N4 and FeVO4 are shifted slightly in IR spectrum of CIB owing to bonding among the moieties. Fig S1 shows the representative structure of CIB junction.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig 2(a) & (b) shows the XRD- diffraction pattern of as prepared CI and CIB. The CI diffractogram shows characteristic peaks of g-C3N4 and FeVO4 which are in good agreement with standard JCPDS file 87-1526 (Ma et al., 2016) and 01-071- 1592 (Kaneti et al., 2013) respectively. The peak at 27.4° indexed as the (002) planes of the interlayer stacking of aromatic units in g-C3N4 with spacing of 0.276nm and 13.1° refers to (100) diffraction peak for interplanar separation of 0.562nm. Further the diffraction peaks observed at 16.5, 25.1, 27.3, and 41.4 were ascribed to the (110), (120), (012), (230) lattice planes of FeVO4 respectively. Besides, no other diffraction peaks were observed in the XRD patterns of CI, indicating the FeVO4/g-C3N4 only a two phase hybrid product. The values of lattice parameters as calculated from the XRD peaks are a = 7.55 Å, b = 10.57 Å, c = 8.28 Å, α = 106.58°, β = 101.28° and γ = 96.68° which refers to triclinic structure of FeVO4. The average crystallite size of CI composite is 18-25 nm which are also in good agreement with TEM data. The fig 2(b) shows XRD pattern of CIB. We observe that most of the scattering comes from biochar which shows why the undoubtedly still present peaks from FeVO4 don’t appear. 3.1.3 XPS analysis In order to verify the chemical status of g-C3N4/FeVO4 and g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2-biochar the X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was done. The survey spectrum for CI is represented in Fig 3(a) which confirms the existence of C, N, Fe, and O and V elements. Fig 3(b) shows the C1s spectrum with fitted peaks at 288.0 eV, (corresponding to sp2 hybridized in aromatic ring) (Cui et al., 2011) 285.21 (sp2 carbon atoms bonded to N) (Yan et al., 2010) & 283.82 eV. The high resolution N1s spectrum (Fig 3c) shows three deconvoluted peaks at 397.96, 398.0 and 399.58 eV corresponding to sp2 hybridized nitrogen, sp3 N-C and C-NH respectively. In addition, in the O 1s spectrum (Fig 3d) the two peaks at 529.15 & 530.52 eV refer to two different types of oxygen attributed to lattice oxygen of FeVO4 and the oxygen in OH groups respectively. The

peaks located at about 713.39 and 724.53 eV Fe 2p3/2 & Fe 2p1/2 respectively as given in Fig 3(e) which also refers to Iron (III) oxidation state (Yu et al., 2016). As shown in V 2p spectrum in Fig 3(f), the V 2p orbital displays the peaks at binding energies of around 523.24 eV and 515.96 eV, which were assigned to V 2p1/2orbital and V 2p3/2orbital, respectively (He et al., 2013). Further the XPS spectrum of CIB (Fig 3f) attribute all the same BE peaks as for CI with slight shifts. However we observe an increase in intensity of N and carbon peaks due to presence of amino modified biochar. The two additional BE peaks at 287.4 and 399.1eV are found for CIB composite which stem from the sp2 bonded carbon in N-containing aromatic rings (N– C=N) of g- C3N4, and N-H forms of N respectively due to the presence of amino group on biochar matrix which was further supported by the FT-IR results. One additional peak at 706.0 eV corresponds to Fe0 present in magnetic biochar. 3.1.4 SEM analysis The surface morphology and microstructure of the prepared sample were investigated by scanning electron microscopy. Fig 4(a) shows a typical lamellar or multilayer stacking structure of g-C3N4. The SEM images of CI are shown in Fig 4 (b), (c) & (d) demonstrating that FeVO4 nanorods are accumulated on g-C3N4 proving the formation of hetero-structure. The SEM micrographs of CIB (Fig 4 e and f) show roughness and increased porosity which is due to the amino modified biochar matrix. The g-C3N4/FeVO4 is well stacked on the biochar matrix.
3.1.5 TEM analysis
Fig. 5(a) & (b) represents TEM image of the CI junction. It is clearly visible that the FeVO4 nanorods are well distributed on graphitic layered graphitic carbon nitride. SAED pattern (Fig 4c) shows the crystalline nature of FeVO4 and CI junction as a whole. Fig 5(d) shows higher resolution TEM image of CI which clearly shows the formation of hetero-junction. The average particle size for CIB is 35-42 nm and for CI is 22-31nm. A higher morphology is observed in TEM images of CIB (Fig 5 e & f) and we observe that CI hetero-junction is uniformly stacked on biochar matrix. CI and CIB hetero-junctions are in nano-range and size is in confirmation with XRD calculations.

Where ECB and EVB are the band edge potentials of conduction band and valence band respectively, Ee is the energy of electrons on hydrogen scale (~4.5 eV), X is the geometric mean of the absolute electronegativity of the constituent atoms on Pearson scale (PAE) and Eg is the band gap of semiconductor in electron volts. The band gap parameters are listed in Table1. On solar exposure, electron-hole pairs are generated for both the semiconductors. The electrons from conduction band of g-C3N4 (-1.24eV) get transferred to CB of FeVO4 (-0.54eV) and similarly holes from VB of FeVO4 (1.66 eV) to less positive VB of g-C3N4 (-1.24eV). Thus there is a vectorial transfer of holes. This leads to a charge separation, increased transport of carriers and a reduced charge recombination. TiO2 has been an important candidate and has been modified suitably for better charge separation and higher solar light absorption (Yan et al., 2015). If we compare the band gap of individual photocatalysts g-C3N4 (2.76eV) and TiO2 (3.20 eV) (Wu et al., 2013) with CI (2.35 eV) & CIB (2.31eV), we observed narrowing of band gap which ultimately leads to the increased harvesting of light and red shifted in visible region. The shift is observed in diffuse reflectance UV-Visible spectrum (Fig 6b). CI exhibited an absorbance edge around 550 nm whereas CIB exhibited an absorbance edge around 600 nm. The charge separation and flow leads to a higher light-harvesting capability and durability. g-C3N4 Photoluminescence spectrum (Fig 6 b) was also used to investigate the efficiency of reduced recombination and charge carrier transfer. Typical emission peak ~450eV is observed for g-C3N4 and 470 eV for FeVO4. However the peaks are nearly absent in PL spectrum of CI as curve becomes nearly flat. The peaks nearly vanish for CIB. In case of CIB biochar also leads to a charge separation via formation of sink for electrons as reported by other experiments. This confirms the successful formation of hetero-junction and reduced charge carrier recombination. 3.1.7 BET studies Fig 7 (a) and (b) represents N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for surface area determination. The specific surface area of CI 62 m2/g and of CIB is 192.5m2/g. The pore volume for CIB is 19cm3g-1 and average pore size of 23nm. Similarly for CI the pore volume is 0.132cm3g-1 and average pore size of 4.5nm. Higher porosity of CIB is due to presence of highly porous biochar.

The biochar matrix provides high surface area and support to the CI junction making it a better adsorbent and photocatalyst. 3.2 Removal of Methyl Paraben and 2-Chlorophenol from simulated waste water The pollutant removal capacity of CIB and CI have been studied by studying removal of noxious pollutants methyl paraben and 2-chlorophenol via adsorption, adsorption followed by photocatalysis, simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis and photo-degradation coupled with photo-ozonation. All experiments for photo-degradation have been performed in natural sunlight. The structures of MeP and 2-CP are given in Fig S2.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Adsorptive removal of MeP & 2-CP
sections.text:
The adsorption of MeP and 2-CP onto Fe-BC and Fe-NH2-BC has been studied and represented in Fig S3. It is clearly evident that amino modified Fe loaded biochar shows a higher adsorption potential as 74.2% of MeP and 54.21% of 2-CP was adsorbed in 2h experiment. The modification of biochar by amino functionalization and Fe loading leads to increased adsorption and magnetic separation. Fig 8 (a) shows adsorption of MeP and 2-CP onto CI and CIB. 79.2% and 52.1% of MeP was adsorbed onto CIB and CI respectively. Similarly for 2-CP, 58.2% and 41.4% adsorption percentage was achieved in presence of CIB and CI respectively. CI has a lower adsorption capacity as compared to CIB due to presence of high surface area of biochar and magnetic separation also. Fig 8(b) and (c) shows first order kinetics of adsorption and Fig 8(d) and (e) represent second order kinetics. The overall adsorption of MeP/2-CP follows second order rate. The rate constants and adsorption capacity are listed in Table S1. The adsorption data is also represented by Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherms. The Langmuir and Freundlich models are given by Eqs. (5) and (6)

Freundlich model is applicable for multilayer adsorption while Langmuir isotherm model is for monolayer adsorption. In this case the adsorption of MeP and 2-CP onto CI and CIB follow Langmuir model with both KL and RL hinting towards favorable model and adsorption. The parameters are listed in Table S2. The maximum

adsorption capacity for MeP is 77.12 mg/g and 57.64 mg/g for CI and CIB respectively. Similarly for 2-CP the adsorption capacity is 54.13mg/g for CIB and 46.23mg/g for CI. Thus CIB behaves as a better adsorbent. 3.2.2 Adsorption followed by photo-degradation (AP) In this experimental condition the suspensions containing pollutant is first kept in dark to establish adsorption-desorption equilibrium and then exposed to sunlight for photo-degradation. The blank photolysis (degradation by irradiation with sunlight without any photocatalyst) of MeP (4.6%) and 2-CP (4.3%) was studied under sunlight and results are given in Fig S4. This shows the persistence and stability of such pollutants in water. Fig 10(a) shows the removal of MeP and 2-CP in presence of CIB and CI under AP system. In presence of CIB 90.1% MeP and 85.3% 2-CP was degraded while the percentages were 71.2% and 68.2 % in case of CI. As expected the adsorption potential of NH2-modified biochar leads to better adsorption of pollutants onto the photocatalyst surface. After complete adsorption onto CIB and CI the presence of reactive oxygen species leads to degradation. The total concentration of MeP at any time is (Kumar et al., 2014)

As explained earlier via band structure and PL results the higher visible absorption and reduced carrier recombination results in higher degradation as compared to FeVO4 and g-C3N4. It is clear that CIB and CI are better photocatalysts.

The kinetics plots are given in Fig 10 (c) and (d). The rate constants and the regression coefficients are listed in Table 5. In presence of CIB the apparent rate constants for MeP and 2- CP degradation are 0.0156 min-1 and 0.0098 min-1. As expected, CIB delivers a better photocatalytic activity than CI. This can be attributed to the fact that the CIB catalyst provides both a very high number of adsorptive sites (higher surface area, predominantly on the biochar) and high functionality. The rate in AP system decreases after some time because of the fact that most of surface has been covered by the pollutant, thus hindering the photo-activity. 3.2.3 Simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis (SAP) In second reaction condition we expose the reactor containing suspension of MeP/2-CP and photocatalyst directly to sunlight. In this system the pollutant is adsorbed on to system and gets attacked by reactive oxygen species generated on solar exposure. Thus it gets degraded as soon as it gets adsorbed. Fig 10(b) shows photo-degradation of MeP and 2-CP under SAP condition in presence of CI and CIB. For FeVO4, g-C3N4, FeVO4/Fe-NH2-biochar (IB) and g-C3N4/ FeNH2-biochar (CB) the results are given in Fig S5. The degradation of MeP follows the order – IB (68.2%) > FeVO4 (55.4%) > CB (55.1%) > g-C3N4 (45.3%). Similar order is observed in case of 2-CP (Fig S5 b). In presence of CIB as photocatalyst 98.4% of MeP and 90.7% of 2-CP is degraded in 90 min of solar irradiation. However, lower degradation is achieved in case of CI (78.4 % of MeP and 76.5 % of 2-CP). MeP and 2-CP are adsorbed onto the surface of CIB better than CI as inferred from adsorption potential of the photocatalysts. When compared to MeP, 2-CP shows less degradation as it binds to the photocatalyst poorly because of lesser functionality. The photocatalytic efficiency is generally enhanced by adsorption of adsorbate onto the photocatalyst. However this also depends on the vacant sites on the surface of the adsorbent or photocatalyst. CIB scores higher than CI because of its higher adsorbing character. In addition from optical band gap studies we observe that optical band gap for CIB is lower than CI which also facilitates higher visible light absorption. When the system is irradiated under visible light, g-C3N4 absorbs light and transfers an electron from its VB to its CB. The excited electrons then migrate to the CB of FeVO4, while the positive holes in the VB of FeVO4 were transferred to the VB of g-C3N4, which reduces recombination. The charge carriers subsequently migrate to the composite surface, producing hydroxyl and superoxide radicals with water and dissolved oxygen, respectively, which can then

14
proceed to oxidize MeP. The electron-hole recombination can reduce the photo-activity. The defects and surface regions on the semiconductor can be the centers of recombination (Yan et al., 2014). But this can be overcome by increasing crystalline, doping or combination with a other semiconductor. In CI junction, the photo-induced electrons would be easily injected from the CB of g-C3N4 to the CB of FeVO4 because the CB of g-C3N4 (-1.24 eV) is more negative than that of FeVO4 (- 0.54 eV). Simultaneously, because the VB edge level of FeVO4 (1.66 eV) is lower than that of g-C3N4 (1.52 eV), holes on the VB edge of FeVO4 will transfer to that of g-C3N4 under the control of the interface. This is represented schematically in Fig 11(a). In such way, there is efficient separation of photo-induced electrons and holes on the n–n heterojunction, which may greatly reduce the recombination of the photoinduced charge carriers, The CIB catalyst is completely magnetically recoverable. Fig 11(b) shows the M-H curve for CIB. The photocatalyst is ferromagnetic with magnetization of 30.2 emu/g. In AP system there is possibility that the surface of CIB/CI gets covered by pollutant and so degradation gets suppressed. However in SAP MeP/2-CP gets adsorbed and gets degraded simultaneously by attack of reactive oxygen species. The electron-hole pair (e-h) produces superoxide ions and hydroxyl radicals.

The photogenerated electrons in FeVO4 are captured by O2 to yield .O2 -, and finally form HO•. On the other hand, the photoinduced holes in g-C3N4 are powerful oxidative species, which can oxidize MeP directly, leading to its decomposition. The ●O2 - reacts with H+ to form hydrogen peroxide radicals (●HO2) (scheme1) which leads to formation of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is a better electron acceptor than oxygen and reduces the chance of oxygen recombination (Nguyen et al., 2015). In addition presence of zero-valent iron in biochar and Fe3+ in CI photocatalyst a possible Fenton process takes place. Scheme 3 shows the Fenton reactions possible. These series of reactions lead to decreased recombination and increase in reactive oxygen species. As per predicted mechanism and band edge positions HO● have been demonstrated to play major roles in the degradation of MeP and 2-CP. Dynamic light scattering technique was used to determine the polarity of CI and CIB in pH 5-6 and 7-8. The surface of both the catalysts is positively charged in pH range 5-6 and negative in higher pH range. The pKa value for 2-CP is 8.53 and for MeP is 8.16 at inherent pH 5.5. Hence at this pH the surface is approximately neutral or slightly positive. However at higher pH both the catalyst and the pollutants will be negatively charged and thus decrease the adsorption. At very low pH 2-CP and MeP will both be protonated and it could also lead to leaching of the photocatalyst. As compared to AP system we achieve higher mineralization of both the pollutants in just 90 min of solar exposure. The overall degradation process in SAP system follows pseudo first order kinetics. Fig 10 (c) and (d) shows the kinetics plots for degradation of MeP and 2-CP respectively. The apparent rate constant (k1) for MeP and 2-CP degradation in presence of CIB are 0.0368 min -1 and 0.0253 min-1. The rates are quite higher than CI, for MeP 0.0146min-1 and for 2-CP 0.0121min1. The rate constants and linear regression coefficients are listed in table 2. 3.2.4 Photo-ozonation Removal of MeP and 2-CP has also been studied via coupling of ozonation with photocatalysis to achieve best results. Fig 12(a) shows ozone profile concentration during ozone decomposition in buffered distilled water in presence of solar light. In the course of the experiment the ozone decomposition is enhanced. Scheme 2 represents the decomposition of ozone in presence of solar spectrum into

H2O2 and .OH. Fig 12(b) represents hydrogen peroxide evolution with time. Hydrogen peroxide promotes the decomposition of O3 in aqueous medium for formation of various reactive oxygen species as represented in Scheme 2. If we compare the hydrogen peroxide generated in our experiments with previous reported ones, the generation is slightly lesser because latter per performed at pH=4. However we have conducted ozonation at pH = 5.5 as per AP and SAP experiments for degradation of MeP and 2-CP. In basic medium HO2 - is formed which interferes in the steps involving the formation of hydroxyl radicals. Coupling of photodegradation with ozonation has been one of the means for decomposition of ozone to produce hydrogen peroxide or hydroxyl radicals (Xiao et al., 2015). Fig 13 (a) shows the degradation of MeP and 2-CP under SAP + O3 and SAP + O3 + photocatalyst system. In absence of catalyst pure photo-ozonation leads to 41.2 % of MeP and 40.3% of 2-CP degradation under solar light. As per scheme 2 first five steps are responsible for the degradation in this condition. However in presence of photocatalyst CIB higher degradation of 99.8% and 99.2% was achieved for MeP and 2-CP respectively in just 60 min. However CI scores slightly inferior as it leads to 81.2% MeP and 80.71% 2-CP degradation in 60min. When photocatalysis and ozonation are carried out simultaneously, the dissolved ozone receives generated electrons from CIB/CI which leads to hydroxyl radical formation and evolution of oxygen. This is shown in last four steps of scheme 2. Thus recombination is reduced and leads to abundance of holes and hydroxyl radicals. Synergistic effect of ozonation and photocatalysis is hence produced (Mehrjouei et al 2015). Thus it leads to symbioses of adsorption, photocatalysis and ozonation. It has been claimed in earlier works that catalytic ozonation leads to partial oxidation and hence lesser organic carbon removal. However when pollutant is adsorbed onto the catalyst, the generation of e-h hole pairs onto hetero-junction takes place. During solar exposure the degradation of ozone leads to formation of hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radicals. However in the presence of electrons which are not able to recombine due to formation of hetero-junction there is a substantial increase in reactive oxygen species and hence the rate of reaction. Good adsorption properties and a suitable interaction among organic pollutant, O3 molecules and catalyst play an important role for degradation via photocatalytic ozonation. Hence CIB behaves as an excellent photocatalyst.

3.2.5 Effect of scavengers In the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, a series of oxidation-reduction reactions take place and in addition to electrons, holes, reactive oxygen species as *O2 - ,*OH etc. are generated. To study the role of various species effect of scavengers as Na-EDTA, 4-hydroxy-2, 2, 6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyloxy (TEMPOL), t-butanol (TBA) on degradation process under SAP and SAP+O3 system was studied. EDTA is a strong hole scavenger which leads to transfer of electron to the VB of CI/CIB thus inhibiting electron-holes recombination. t-butanol is hydroxyl radical scavenger and its presence in aqueous medium can negatively influence photocatalytic ozonation (Beltran et al., 2009). The greater inhibition of the reaction through alcohol as radical scavenger indicates that HO* plays a more important role in the photocatalytic degradation of MeP and 2-CP (Doorslaer et al., 2012). However, it is also observed that on addition of TEMPOL, the degradation is also inhibited but to a lesser extent than t-butanol. Hence superoxide radical anion also plays as a reactive oxygen species responsible to some extent. From band edge positions (Fig11a) it is inferred that redox potential of CB edge of FeVO4 (-0.54eV) and g-C3N4 (-1.24 eV) is more negative than E (O2/ *O2 -) = -0.33 eV (Mousavi et al., 2016). Thus *O2 - is also responsible species. E (*OH/OH-) = 1.99 eV (Yao et al., 2005) and thus hydroxyl radicals are formed as VB of both the semiconductor are positive. Even redox of E (O2/H2O2) = -0.695 (Mousavi et al., 2016) eV and - 1.24 eV of CB of g-C3N4 and hydrogen peroxide is produced. In this manner in presence of Fe, fenton reaction is feasible leading to formation of hydroxyl free radicals as per scheme 3. 2.2.6 Performance of photo-catalysts under various conditions and pH Figure 15 shows representative image of how the photocatalysts behave under AP, SAP and SAP + O3 system. In AP and SAP system CIB and CI behave as adsorbents as well as photocataysts as discussed earlier also. However the SAP system leads to higher degradation of both MeP and 2-CP. In case of SAP coupled with ozonation, three phenomena of adsorption, photocatalysis and ozonation play important roles. If we observe the effect of scavengers on the rate of reaction, it is inferred that in case of degradation via CIB and CI under AP & SAP systems hydroxyl radicals as well as superoxide anion radicals play an important role in the degradation. If we compare our work with the previously reported works we observe that rarely photoozonation coupled with photocatalysis has been utilized for degradation of parabens. In a recent work 98.2% of 2-CP was degraded in 8h (pollutant conc. 20mg/L) under lamp (Sharma et al., 2016). In similar work 92.2% of 2-CP (50mg/L) was photo-degraded using mesostructured silica nanoparticles modified with 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane and impregnated with FeOOH (Jusoh et al., 2015). Complete removal of 2-CP was achieved within 120 min in the BiCu9/Bi 0 - H2O2 system (Zhang et al., 2016). In a recent work almost complete solar induced removal of methyl paraben (10mgL-1) was achieved with in 240 min (Velegraki et al., 2015). However in our CIB + SAP + O3 we achieve almost complete removal of MeP in just 60 min of solar exposure with an initial concentration of 20mgL-1. In another case B doped diamond was used for 60% of MeP mineralization by sono-electrochemical method (Steter et al., 2014). Methyl paraben was degraded to a 60% by photo-fenton process (Zuniga-Benitez et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 3.2.7 Mechanistic pathway of degradation
sections.text:
The identified intermediates were summarized in Table 4 & 5 together with their m/Z ratios. The LC-MS spectrum of suspension of MeP and 2-CP after 30 min of experiment in SAP + CIB system is given in Fig S6. On the basis of previous and current study the degradation pathways are suggested including decarboxylation, hydroxylation, dealkylation, methylation, and cleavage of MeP molecule are described as major transformation mechanisms (Lin et al., 2009). The intermediates identified have aromatic as well some aliphatic intermediates suggesting that ring cleavage occur at some point of the reaction. In a typical mechanism all the intermediates are formed mainly by the HO● attack on MeP molecule, the reaction of MeP molecule with photogenerated holes in CIB and direct oxidation of MeP by dissolved oxygen in water. Firstly, MeP is attacked by HO● radicals at –CH3 and –H in the aromatic ring to produce 4-hydroxybenzoic acid and dihydroxybenzoic acid methyl ester. Because of coupling at high concentration 1, 2- benzenedicarboxylic acid dimethyl ester is also formed. These products are further oxidized into the phenol, which is attacked by HO• radicals to form the isomers of 1, 2-dihydroxybenzene and 1, 4-dihydroxybenzene. Benzoquinones are well known intermediates of the phenol photo oxidation (Okamoto et al., 1985). Further 1, 2- dihydroxybenzene is transformed into 2, 4-hexadienedioic acid by the opening of the aromatic ring observed throughout the photocatalysis process, which is also reported in the literature (Chuang et al., 2015). 2, 4-Hexadienedioic acid is oxidized into many simpler acids or ketones through some reactions, attack by HO●. This has been represented in scheme 5.
In case of photodegradation of 2-CP photo-generated holes produce ●OH by interacting with
aqueous system which attacks 2-CP molecule resulting the dechlorination and produces 1, 2- Benzendiol.Benzoquinones and chlorinated benzoquinones are also reported earlier (Zhou et al., 2011). The reaction may further proceed to formation of 1, 2, 4-Benzenetriol which ultimately leading to the formation of various intermediates and finally mineralizes into simpler inorganic moieties (Grabowska et al., 2012). The scheme 6 shows the degradation pathway for 2-CP.

sections.heading: 4. TOC, Cyto-toxicity & Reusability evaluation
sections.text:
The mineralization of MeP and dechlorination 2-CP was also evaluated using total organic carbon and cyto-toxicity analysis of treated water. Fig 16 (a) shows % TOC removal for degradation of MeP and 2-CP in presence of CIB as photocatalyst under SAP and SAP + O3 system. A 41.2% and 40.3% TOC removal for MeP and 2-CP respectively was observed after 90 min of experiment. However in case SAP+ O3 + CIB system 74.2% & 73.9% TOC was achieved in just 90 min for degradation of MeP and 2-CP respectively. Thus it is confirmed that
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
24
a sententious mineralization of pollutants takes place which is also tested by the CO2 emission detected using a Ca(OH)2 test. The effect of mineralization products was analyzed on human PBL by MTT assay. MTT is a pale yellow tetrazolium salt reduced by mitochondrial dehydrogenases to yield a dark blue formazan product. As revealed by MTT assay, after 24 h of incubation the treated water (CIB + MeP +SAP) did not affect mitochondrial function and the viability of PBL (Fig 16 b) which suggest that these compounds are non-toxic to human cells. Thus TOC removal and cytotoxicity analysis reveal that we are able to achieve usable water and also indicate the potential of the photocatalysts and methodology. We have utilized the CIB composite catalyst for various cycles for MeP and 2-CP degradation under SAP system. The results are given in Fig 16 (c). A degradation of 98.4% (MeP) was achieved for first cycle for CIB and for sixth cycle 97.4 was achieved. In case of 2-CP the degradation decreases from, 90.7% to 89.1% for sixth cycle. The decrease in photocatalytic activity on subsequent usages may be due to accumulation of intermediates and pollutant molecules on the surface of the photocatalyst blocking the active site leading to a decrease in formation of reactive oxygen species. CIB composite catalyst is stable, reusable and magnetically recoverable.
5. Conclusion:
In this study hybrid hetero-assembly of g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2-biochar was fabricated and successfully utilized for visible assisted photodegradation of methyl paraben and 2- chlorophenol. The existence of magnetism via FeVO4 and Fe loaded biochar leads to magnetic separation from aqueous system. Utilizing g-C3N4/FeVO4 and g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2-Biochar for removal of pollutants via adsorption (A), adsorption followed by photocatalysis (AP), simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis (SAP) and photo-ozonation coupled with photocatalysis reaction conditions. The co-existence of FeVO4 and Fe is favorable for higher visible absorption and increase in photoactivity. The heterojunction leads to better charge separation, reduced charge carriers recombination and higher photodegradation activity. Both the junctions show highest activity in Photo-ozonation coupled with photocatalysis system with almost complete mineralization of MeP and 2-CP in 60 minutes of solar-irradiation + O3. Based on scavenger effect, TOC studies and LC-MS degradation pathway has been proposed highlighting major reactive species. The removal of total organic carbon and cytotoxicity tests

US CR

PT ED

(for water obtained after MeP degradation) on human PBL provide a reference for removal of noxious pollutants in real systems.

metadata.abstractText: In this research work we report synthesis of g-C3N4/FeVO4 (CI) and g-C3N4/FeVO4/Fe@NH2Biochar (CIB) nano-hetero assemblies for removal of methyl paraben (MeP) and 2cholrophenol (2-CP) via adsorption, photocatalysis and photo-ozonation. CI and CIB have been characterized by FT-IR, X-ray diffraction (XRD) , X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy(TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), UV-Vis spectroscopy, photoluminescence (PL), vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM), BraunerEmmet Teller surface area analyzer (BET). CIB shows good photocatalytic activity owing to higher specific area, nanosheet porous structure, stability, broader solar spectrum response and reduced charge carriers recombination. Fe@NH2-biochar facilitates the degradation via high adsorption capability due to reduced recombination, better charge separation, adsorption and acting of biochar as sink of electrons. The CIB photocatalytic system was tested under three experimental conditions for photodegradation of MeP and 2-CP; adsorption followed by photodegradation (AP); simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis (SAP); SAP+O3. An apparent M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 synergism between adsorption, photocatalysis and photo-ozonation brings out excellent and promising results. 98.4% of MeP and 90.7% of CP degradation was achieved under simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis in presence of CIB. The results were analyzed in terms of reaction kinetics, adsorption isotherms, scavenger effect, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS), Total Organic Carbon (TOC) analysis and cytotoxicity analysis of treated water. An efficient TOC removal 74.2 & 73.9 % for MeP and 2-CP were respectively achieved under SAP+O3+CIB photocatalysis system. Degradation pathways have been proposed for degradation of MeP and CP thorough photo-degradation and photo-ozonation. The cyto-toxicity studies on Human peripheral blood lymphocytes provide a reference for removal of noxious pollutants in real systems. This experimental work paves a way to design tuneable simple junctions for photocatalytic applications by utilizing various experimental protocols.
